elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig1">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Normalized IR vibrational frequencies of styrene monomer calculated by quantum-chemical methods. (Results are given by the hollow asterisks; the drop lines are drawn to aid viewing).</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  Normalized IR vibrational frequencies of styrene monomer calculated by quantum-chemical methods. (Results are given by the hollow asterisks; the drop lines are drawn to aid viewing).

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig2">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">FT-IR spectra of (a) styrene monomer and (b) polystyrene resin bead.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  FT-IR spectra of (a) styrene monomer and (b) polystyrene resin bead.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig3">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Computational and experimental IR vibrational spectra of styrene monomer. (a) Computational vibrational frequencies (results are given by the hollow asterisks; the drop lines are drawn to aid viewing). (b) Simulated infrared spectrum through Gaussian convolutions. (c) Experimental FT-IR spectrum.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  Computational and experimental IR vibrational spectra of styrene monomer. (a) Computational vibrational frequencies (results are given by the hollow asterisks; the drop lines are drawn to aid viewing). (b) Simulated infrared spectrum through Gaussian convolutions. (c) Experimental FT-IR spectrum.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig4">
<ce:label>Fig. 4</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Vibrational analysis of styrene monomer. (Absorption peaks from impurities and other sources are indicated by the asterisks and the rectangle).</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr4"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 4  Vibrational analysis of styrene monomer. (Absorption peaks from impurities and other sources are indicated by the asterisks and the rectangle).

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig5">
<ce:label>Fig. 5</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Experimental FT-IR spectra of (a) styrene monomer and (b) polystyrene resin bead. (Absorption peaks suitable for encoding are indicated by the asterisks).</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr5"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 5  Experimental FT-IR spectra of (a) styrene monomer and (b) polystyrene resin bead. (Absorption peaks suitable for encoding are indicated by the asterisks).

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">A novel strategy is described for the vibrational spectroscopic encoding of polystyrene resin bead by combining FT-IR measurements and quantum-chemical computations. The FT-IR spectra of styrene monomer and a polystyrene resin bead were recorded and vibrational frequency computations for styrene monomer were performed using the DFT B3LYP/6-31G* method. A detailed analysis of the vibrational characteristics of styrene monomer and polystyrene resin bead is presented based on combining the FT-IR measurements and the quantum-chemical computations. Results indicate that several absorption peaks in the FT-IR spectrum of styrene monomer may come from unpredictable impurity molecules inside the styrene sample and/or from the measurement apparatus itself, which may disturb the analysis of the vibrational spectrum of polystyrene resin bead. The vibrational spectroscopic barcodes for the polystyrene resin bead were obtained by comparing the FT-IR spectra of styrene monomer and the polystyrene resin bead.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A novel strategy is described for the vibrational spectroscopic encoding of polystyrene resin bead by combining FT-IR measurements and quantum-chemical computations. The FT-IR spectra of styrene monomer and a polystyrene resin bead were recorded and vibrational frequency computations for styrene monomer were performed using the DFT B3LYP/6-31G* method. A detailed analysis of the vibrational characteristics of styrene monomer and polystyrene resin bead is presented based on combining the FT-IR measurements and the quantum-chemical computations. Results indicate that several absorption peaks in the FT-IR spectrum of styrene monomer may come from unpredictable impurity molecules inside the styrene sample and/or from the measurement apparatus itself, which may disturb the analysis of the vibrational spectrum of polystyrene resin bead. The vibrational spectroscopic barcodes for the polystyrene resin bead were obtained by comparing the FT-IR spectra of styrene monomer and the polystyrene resin bead.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Combinatorial chemistry concepts are changing academic research in many disciplines, especially in drug development as a large number of compounds can be generated and screened for specific biological or biochemical function .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Combinatorial chemistry concepts are changing academic research in many disciplines, especially in drug development as a large number of compounds can be generated and screened for specific biological or biochemical function .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">One particular combinatorial approach is the one-bead-one-compound (OBOC) method that was introduced more than 10 years ago . Using the OBOC combinatorial library method, millions of random compound beads can be generated such that each single polymeric bead carries one particular compound. Bead libraries are screened, and positive beads are isolated for structure analysis. Potential applications of the OBOC approach for fast high-throughput systems for drug discovery have attracted intense interest during the last decade .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: One particular combinatorial approach is the one-bead-one-compound (OBOC) method that was introduced more than 10 years ago . Using the OBOC combinatorial library method, millions of random compound beads can be generated such that each single polymeric bead carries one particular compound. Bead libraries are screened, and positive beads are isolated for structure analysis. Potential applications of the OBOC approach for fast high-throughput systems for drug discovery have attracted intense interest during the last decade .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Nevertheless, decoding of the polymeric bead is often the bottleneck of the OBOC combinatorial method. Multiple encoding methods have been developed to solve this problem, and the subject has been reviewed . In particular, Fenniri and co-workers  have recently reported a novel encoding method for polystyrene-based resin beads prepared with built-in IR and Raman spectroscopy barcodes. By incorporating different styrene-derivatives with distinctive IR and Raman spectroscopic characteristic into styrene monomers, polystyrene co-polymers are prepared that are encoded with specific spectroscopic tags. Because most laboratories possess a standard Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) measurement apparatus, it is an inexpensive encoding method.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Nevertheless, decoding of the polymeric bead is often the bottleneck of the OBOC combinatorial method. Multiple encoding methods have been developed to solve this problem, and the subject has been reviewed . In particular, Fenniri and co-workers  have recently reported a novel encoding method for polystyrene-based resin beads prepared with built-in IR and Raman spectroscopy barcodes. By incorporating different styrene-derivatives with distinctive IR and Raman spectroscopic characteristic into styrene monomers, polystyrene co-polymers are prepared that are encoded with specific spectroscopic tags. Because most laboratories possess a standard Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) measurement apparatus, it is an inexpensive encoding method.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">However, it is particularly important to notice that in order to make this IR vibrational spectroscopic encoding method efficient and practical, the polystyrene-based resin beads must be carefully and correctly encoded. The IR spectra of polystyrene-based resin beads usually contain a large number of vibrational peaks  that are not only contributed by the intrinsic vibrational modes of polystyrene and its co-polymers but also by other unavoidable and unpredictable impurity molecules inside the polymeric bead and/or by the measurement apparatus itself. In other words, to obtain an accurate encoding of the FT-IR spectra, reliable assignments of all vibrational bands are essential. Fortunately, for this purpose quantum-chemical methods, ranging from semi-empirical to the density functional theory (DFT) approaches, are invaluable tools . Among these, the DFT method, particularly combined with the Becke3-Lee-Yang-Parr (B3LYP) hybrid functional method, has evolved to a powerful quantum-chemical tool for the determination of the electronic structure of molecules and is the most used method since it provides vibrational frequencies usually in fair agreement with experiment .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: However, it is particularly important to notice that in order to make this IR vibrational spectroscopic encoding method efficient and practical, the polystyrene-based resin beads must be carefully and correctly encoded. The IR spectra of polystyrene-based resin beads usually contain a large number of vibrational peaks  that are not only contributed by the intrinsic vibrational modes of polystyrene and its co-polymers but also by other unavoidable and unpredictable impurity molecules inside the polymeric bead and/or by the measurement apparatus itself. In other words, to obtain an accurate encoding of the FT-IR spectra, reliable assignments of all vibrational bands are essential. Fortunately, for this purpose quantum-chemical methods, ranging from semi-empirical to the density functional theory (DFT) approaches, are invaluable tools . Among these, the DFT method, particularly combined with the Becke3-Lee-Yang-Parr (B3LYP) hybrid functional method, has evolved to a powerful quantum-chemical tool for the determination of the electronic structure of molecules and is the most used method since it provides vibrational frequencies usually in fair agreement with experiment .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In this letter, the vibrational characteristics of styrene monomer and polystyrene resin bead are presented. By combining quantum-chemical calculations and FT-IR measurements, a novel strategy for the vibrational spectroscopic encoding of polystyrene resin bead is introduced, which is an example for the vibrational spectroscopic encoding of other polystyrene-based resin beads and can make the vibrational spectroscopic encoding method developed by Fenniri and co-workers more accurate and practical.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this letter, the vibrational characteristics of styrene monomer and polystyrene resin bead are presented. By combining quantum-chemical calculations and FT-IR measurements, a novel strategy for the vibrational spectroscopic encoding of polystyrene resin bead is introduced, which is an example for the vibrational spectroscopic encoding of other polystyrene-based resin beads and can make the vibrational spectroscopic encoding method developed by Fenniri and co-workers more accurate and practical.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The styrene monomer was reagent grade, distilled under reduced pressure to remove the stabilizers and then stored at 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The FT-IR spectrum of styrene monomer was measured in the liquid phase at room temperature using a Brucker EQUINOX55 FT-IR spectrometer, at 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> resolution. The polystyrene resin bead (Chloromethylated polystyrene, 1% cross-linked with divinylbenzene, 1.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol/g typical loading of 4-chloromethylstyrene, particle size 100–200 mesh) was purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification. The bead and KBr were thoroughly mixed and the mixture was pressed to form a pellet, then the spectrum was recorded using the same FT-IR spectrometer at 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> resolution.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

The styrene monomer was reagent grade, distilled under reduced pressure to remove the stabilizers and then stored at 4°C. The FT-IR spectrum of styrene monomer was measured in the liquid phase at room temperature using a Brucker EQUINOX55 FT-IR spectrometer, at 1cm-1 resolution. The polystyrene resin bead (Chloromethylated polystyrene, 1% cross-linked with divinylbenzene, 1.0mmol/g typical loading of 4-chloromethylstyrene, particle size 100-200 mesh) was purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification. The bead and KBr were thoroughly mixed and the mixture was pressed to form a pellet, then the spectrum was recorded using the same FT-IR spectrometer at 2cm-1 resolution.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Computational details</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The molecular geometry optimization and vibrational frequency computation were performed on an IBM Intellistation 37C computer using the <ce:small-caps>gaussian</ce:small-caps> 03W software package . The DFT B3LYP method in conjunction with a 6-31G* basis set were employed. The final calculated IR spectrum was generated through Gaussian convolutions with a full width at half maximum (FWHM) of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Computational details

The molecular geometry optimization and vibrational frequency computation were performed on an IBM Intellistation 37C computer using the gaussian 03W software package . The DFT B3LYP method in conjunction with a 6-31G* basis set were employed. The final calculated IR spectrum was generated through Gaussian convolutions with a full width at half maximum (FWHM) of 10cm-1.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Throughout this work the discussion of the calculated vibrational frequencies is based mainly on the results obtained by the DFT B3LYP/6-31G* method because the combined use of the DFT B3LYP method and the standard split valence basis set 6-31G* has been previously shown  to provide an excellent compromise between accuracy and computational efficiency of vibrational spectra for large and medium-size organic molecules.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Throughout this work the discussion of the calculated vibrational frequencies is based mainly on the results obtained by the DFT B3LYP/6-31G* method because the combined use of the DFT B3LYP method and the standard split valence basis set 6-31G* has been previously shown  to provide an excellent compromise between accuracy and computational efficiency of vibrational spectra for large and medium-size organic molecules.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">To aid in mode assignments, the direct comparison between FT-IR experimental and calculated vibrational frequencies considered both the frequency sequence and the intensity pattern. It is worth noting that the vibrational frequencies obtained by quantum-chemical computations are typically larger than their experimental counterparts  and they have to be scaled by empirical scaling factors <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> ranging from 0.8 to 1.0. These scaling factors depend both on the method and basis sets and they are determined by minimizing the residual errors between the experimental and calculated vibrational frequencies . Thus, prior to comparison of the DFT B3LYP/6-31G* calculated frequencies and the experimental counterparts, the appropriate frequency scaling factor (0.9613) derived by Wong and by Scott and Radom  was used. Using this scaling factor, the root mean square (rms) error for the frequencies of the styrene monomer was calculated through the following equation

elements.clean_text: To aid in mode assignments, the direct comparison between FT-IR experimental and calculated vibrational frequencies considered both the frequency sequence and the intensity pattern. It is worth noting that the vibrational frequencies obtained by quantum-chemical computations are typically larger than their experimental counterparts  and they have to be scaled by empirical scaling factors λ ranging from 0.8 to 1.0. These scaling factors depend both on the method and basis sets and they are determined by minimizing the residual errors between the experimental and calculated vibrational frequencies . Thus, prior to comparison of the DFT B3LYP/6-31G* calculated frequencies and the experimental counterparts, the appropriate frequency scaling factor (0.9613) derived by Wong and by Scott and Radom  was used. Using this scaling factor, the root mean square (rms) error for the frequencies of the styrene monomer was calculated through the following equation      rms =      ∑ i N     ( λ  ω i  th   -  ω i  exp   )  2    N       where    ω i  th     are the calculated frequencies,    ω i  exp     are the experimental frequencies (cm-1) and N is the sum of all the vibrational modes for the molecules considered.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The scaled vibrational frequencies of styrene monomer are presented in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>, where two main vibration regions (0–1700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, 3000–3200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) could be observed. The FT-IR spectra of styrene monomer and polystyrene resin bead were measured and are shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>. A large absorption band located at 3200–3800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> could be observed in (b), which is probably attributed to the absorption of water inside the resin bead. Additionally, it is pointed out that a co-monomer added to the polymerization mixture below ∼10% (w/w) threshold does not display strong and unique vibrations . Therefore, although the polystyrene resin bead studied in this letter is a kind of chloromethylated styrene-divinylbenzene resin, the FT-IR spectrum of this bead is still dominated by the styrene monomer, as the content of chloromethylstyrene and divinylbenzene is far below 10% threshold. As shown in (b), the vibrational spectrum of the polystyrene resin bead in the region larger than 2000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> consisted of several absorption bands with few structural characteristics, which indicates that it is extremely difficult to obtain accurate vibrational assignment and spectroscopic barcode in this region. On the other hand, it should be pointed out that vibrational frequencies lower than 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> are usually unmeasured in a conventional FT-IR spectrometer. Taking all the above information into consideration, the vibrational frequency analysis was restricted to the frequency range 400–2000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The scaled vibrational frequencies of styrene monomer are presented in  , where two main vibration regions (0-1700cm-1, 3000-3200cm-1) could be observed. The FT-IR spectra of styrene monomer and polystyrene resin bead were measured and are shown in  . A large absorption band located at 3200-3800cm-1 could be observed in (b), which is probably attributed to the absorption of water inside the resin bead. Additionally, it is pointed out that a co-monomer added to the polymerization mixture below ~10% (w/w) threshold does not display strong and unique vibrations . Therefore, although the polystyrene resin bead studied in this letter is a kind of chloromethylated styrene-divinylbenzene resin, the FT-IR spectrum of this bead is still dominated by the styrene monomer, as the content of chloromethylstyrene and divinylbenzene is far below 10% threshold. As shown in (b), the vibrational spectrum of the polystyrene resin bead in the region larger than 2000cm-1 consisted of several absorption bands with few structural characteristics, which indicates that it is extremely difficult to obtain accurate vibrational assignment and spectroscopic barcode in this region. On the other hand, it should be pointed out that vibrational frequencies lower than 400cm-1 are usually unmeasured in a conventional FT-IR spectrometer. Taking all the above information into consideration, the vibrational frequency analysis was restricted to the frequency range 400-2000cm-1.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">

<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor> summarizes a detailed assignment of the computational and experimental frequencies of styrene monomer by considering both the frequency sequence and the intensity pattern. The reported vibrational frequencies  obtained by the DFT B3LYP/6-311++G** method are also presented in  to estimate the computational accuracy of the results. However, it should be pointed out that the vibrational frequencies of the styrene molecule reported by Granadino-Roldán et al.  had been scaled using several scaling factors in different frequency regions to obtain a small rms deviation. Therefore, the computations of this report based on the DFT B3LYP/6-31G* method give satisfactory results.</ce:para>

Therefore, the computations of this report based on the DFT B3LYP/6-31G* method give satisfactory results.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">To present a more clear understanding on the vibrational characteristics of the styrene molecule, the separate vibrational frequencies calculated by quantum-chemical methods were generated into a final IR spectrum through Gaussian convolutions with a full width at half maximum (FWHM) of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>(b)). After careful observation of the calculated vibrational frequencies and the FT-IR spectrum of the styrene molecule (see  and ), one could notice that some absorption peaks in the FT-IR spectrum of the styrene monomer could not be found in their computational counterparts, which implied that the experimental FT-IR spectrum of styrene monomer (see (c)) contains absorption peaks contributed by unpredictable impurity molecules inside the styrene sample and/or from the measurement apparatus itself (shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>). If one has to use the FT-IR spectrum of styrene monomer to aid an analysis of the FT-IR spectrum of polystyrene resin bead, one must pay particular attention to avoid wrong assignment of these peaks, which may lead to wrong spectroscopic barcodes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To present a more clear understanding on the vibrational characteristics of the styrene molecule, the separate vibrational frequencies calculated by quantum-chemical methods were generated into a final IR spectrum through Gaussian convolutions with a full width at half maximum (FWHM) of 10cm-1 (see  (b)). After careful observation of the calculated vibrational frequencies and the FT-IR spectrum of the styrene molecule (see  and ), one could notice that some absorption peaks in the FT-IR spectrum of the styrene monomer could not be found in their computational counterparts, which implied that the experimental FT-IR spectrum of styrene monomer (see (c)) contains absorption peaks contributed by unpredictable impurity molecules inside the styrene sample and/or from the measurement apparatus itself (shown in  ). If one has to use the FT-IR spectrum of styrene monomer to aid an analysis of the FT-IR spectrum of polystyrene resin bead, one must pay particular attention to avoid wrong assignment of these peaks, which may lead to wrong spectroscopic barcodes.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">After a careful analysis of the experimental FT-IR spectrum of the styrene monomer, assignments of the vibrational spectroscopic encoding become possible and easy. It is known that the polymerization of styrene monomer into a polystyrene resin bead involves only the vinyl moiety of the styrene molecule and leads to small changes in the vibrational characteristic of the benzene ring. A proper assignment of the vibrational characteristic of apolystyrene resin bead could be made simply through careful comparison between the FT-IR spectrum of the styrene monomer and a polystyrene resin bead because most of the vibrational modes are nearly undisturbed before and after polymerization. The assignments are shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>. Vibrational peaks suitable for encoding are indicated by the asterisks in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor> and are listed in .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: After a careful analysis of the experimental FT-IR spectrum of the styrene monomer, assignments of the vibrational spectroscopic encoding become possible and easy. It is known that the polymerization of styrene monomer into a polystyrene resin bead involves only the vinyl moiety of the styrene molecule and leads to small changes in the vibrational characteristic of the benzene ring. A proper assignment of the vibrational characteristic of apolystyrene resin bead could be made simply through careful comparison between the FT-IR spectrum of the styrene monomer and a polystyrene resin bead because most of the vibrational modes are nearly undisturbed before and after polymerization. The assignments are shown in  . Vibrational peaks suitable for encoding are indicated by the asterisks in   and are listed in .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Finally, it should be noted that the encoding method of this report is based on a combined FT-IR and computational study of the vibrational spectra of a polymer resin bead. The method could not only be applied to the vibrational spectroscopic encoding of the polystyrene resin bead, but also could theoretically be extended to the encoding of other polymer resin beads, especially those polystyrene-based resin beads reported by Fenniri and co-workers .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Finally, it should be noted that the encoding method of this report is based on a combined FT-IR and computational study of the vibrational spectra of a polymer resin bead. The method could not only be applied to the vibrational spectroscopic encoding of the polystyrene resin bead, but also could theoretically be extended to the encoding of other polymer resin beads, especially those polystyrene-based resin beads reported by Fenniri and co-workers .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The analysis of the vibrational characteristics of styrene monomer and a polystyrene resin bead is presented in this letter. By combining quantum-chemical computations and FT-IR measurements of styrene monomer, the vibrational characteristic in the frequency range from 400 to 2000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> is discussed. Several absorption peaks in the FT-IR spectrum of styrene monomer resulted from unpredictable impurity molecules inside the styrene sample and/or from the measurement apparatus itself, therefore care must be taken to avoid wrong assignments in analyzing the spectrum of a polystyrene resin bead. Results indicated that a proper assignment of the vibrational characteristics of polystyrene resin bead could be made simply through comparison of the FT-IR spectrum of styrene monomer and a polystyrene resin bead. Moreover, by carefully comparing between the FT-IR spectra of styrene monomer and a polystyrene resin bead, the vibrational spectroscopic barcodes for that polystyrene resin bead could be obtained.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The analysis of the vibrational characteristics of styrene monomer and a polystyrene resin bead is presented in this letter. By combining quantum-chemical computations and FT-IR measurements of styrene monomer, the vibrational characteristic in the frequency range from 400 to 2000cm-1 is discussed. Several absorption peaks in the FT-IR spectrum of styrene monomer resulted from unpredictable impurity molecules inside the styrene sample and/or from the measurement apparatus itself, therefore care must be taken to avoid wrong assignments in analyzing the spectrum of a polystyrene resin bead. Results indicated that a proper assignment of the vibrational characteristics of polystyrene resin bead could be made simply through comparison of the FT-IR spectrum of styrene monomer and a polystyrene resin bead. Moreover, by carefully comparing between the FT-IR spectra of styrene monomer and a polystyrene resin bead, the vibrational spectroscopic barcodes for that polystyrene resin bead could be obtained.
